newsitem.title: USA: US FDA to issue milk label rule Wednesday.
newsitem.headline: US FDA to issue milk label rule Wednesday.

text.p: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration plans to issue a new milk label rule on Wednesday that will rename two percent milk "reduced fat" instead of "low-fat," an FDA spokeswoman said Tuesday.
In addition, the agency said the rule will allow skim milk to be called "fat-free" or "no-fat." One percent milk will hold on to its "low-fat" moniker.

The FDA was galvanized to act after food law implemented in 1993 specified "low-fat" food contain no more than three grams of fat in a serving. By contrast, a typical eight ounce glass of two percent milk has almost five grams of fat.
The milk rule, which will be published in the Federal Register, goes into effect in January 1998. FDA estimates it will cost milk producers about $1.5 million overall.

The Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer group which has been pressing for the changes since 1987, applauded the FDA's action, saying the new labels would help consumers choose healthier dairy products.

"The FDA's previous labelling scheme misled consumers into thinking that 2% milk was low in fat, and many people switched from whole to 2% thinking they had sharply cut their fat intake," CSPI's Bruce Silverglade said in a statement.
"While 2% milk is certainly more healthful than whole milk, 2% milk is not a low-fat food," he added.
